Title: Fire in a floating-roof tank containing hydrocarbons
LessonsLearned: <p>The refinery’s February 2015 analysis of the incident highlighted the need to reassess the frequency of potential accidents arising in the storage tank area when updating the safety report.<br>Following the accident, the control authority has imposed the following measures on the plant operator:<br>- installation of suitable detection systems capable of promptly alerting the control room to tank roof anomalies (installation on all floating-roof atmospheric tanks of a floating roof monitoring system capable of assessing the slope of the roof),<br>- checks on roofs, caissons, ladders and tank drainage systems,<br>- development of a special monitoring plan for floating-roof tanks with reference to standard API 653, check list appendix C<br>- regular planning of dimensional measurements,<br>- revision of the procedure for inspecting and maintaining tanks for hydrocarbon products</p>
EmergencyResponce_Descr:
<p>From 13.50 on 25 September 2014, the tank was being filled.</p>
<p>At about 9.30 on 26 September 2014, during a patrol they were making owing to the presence of odours, the operations staff detected the presence of virgin naphtha in a limited area of the tank roof. Checks were made immediately and showed that the product was escaping because the western side of the roof was starting to sink as it was taking in liquid from the pontoon sections on the same side.<br>The filling of the tank was interrupted at about 9.40 on 26 September 2014.<br>At about 10.30 on 26 September 2014, the refinery’s management decided to empty the tank as per the operating manual, in addition to implementing all the necessary preventive measures to ensure safety, namely: continuous attendance of firefighting vehicles; preventive covering of the product on the roof with a foam extinguisher; presence, in continuous shifts, of firefighting and technical operations teams for the emptying operation.<br>The layer of extinguisher was applied to the product on the roof at about 10.45 on 26 September 2014.<br>The operations staff started emptying TK&nbsp;513 at about 12.20 on 26 September 2014.<br>In the hours that followed, the transfer of the product continued, whilst the layer of extinguishing foam was maintained by means of successive top-ups that were needed both to cover the product on the roof and owing to increased wind intensity.<br>At about 0.45 on 27 September 2014, the fuel was found to have started leaking and then the fire to have broken out on the tank roof. The level of the tank was estimated to be about 5.5&nbsp;m (it had not been possible to gauge the level for several hours), corresponding to a volume of virgin naphtha of about 30&nbsp;000 m<sup>3</sup>. The internal emergency plan was put into action. The municipal and provincial fire brigades were notified.<br>The tank’s fire protection (cooling and foam spraying) systems were activated immediately. The cooling systems of three adjacent tanks were turned on. The cooling systems of two tanks located further to the south, beyond the embankment of a former railway, were later also turned on. It was possible to keep tank shell temperatures under control with the aid of a thermal sensor. Firefighting equipment and perimeter hydrants were used to protect the lines of transfer of the product in TK&nbsp;513 from irradiance (north side), as was the rack to the south of the tank so as to prevent fire spreading to the vegetation on the trackbed of the former railway.<br>The fire brigade arrived on the scene. At about 2.00 on 27 September 2014, transfer of the product in TK513, interrupted when the emergency arose, was resumed in order to minimise the quantity of product burned.<br>At about 10.00 on 27 September 2014, the most intense phase of the fire seemed to have ended; there were far fewer flames but there was still some smoke activity. The tank's firefighting systems were found to be still active. The on-site and external firefighting teams remained in attendance and monitored the situation.<br>The end of the emergency was declared at about 17.30 on 27 September 2014.<br>On 28 September 2014, the situation was stable, with just one spot fire in the south side of the tank. In the meantime, the cooling of the tank shell, using the cooling ring and monitors, and the removal of the product both continued, although the pump was activated discontinuously by the operator.<br>Traces of smoke could still be detected in the air.<br>From 04.00 to 09.00 on 29 September 2014 there was a resurgence of smoke due to a number of residual spot fires.<br>There was another resurgence of smoke at approx. 9.00-14.00 on 30 September 2014, again due to a number of residual spot fires.<br>&nbsp;In response to this, action is being taken, together with the provincial fire brigade HQ, to put in place fixed foam spraying systems with mounted monitors (including two high-power (7&nbsp;000 and 10&nbsp;000 lt/min) systems) in order to extinguish residual spot fires more quickly.<br>It was then decided to revert to cooling the shell and draining the tank.<br>At about 23.00 on 3 October, all the spot fires had been extinguished.<br>The company stated that the internal emergency plan (IEP) had been put into action immediately and had dealt with the emergency. As decided by the Prefecture, the external emergency plan (EEP) was not put into action.</p>

Reasons.ItemDescription: Substances involved: greater than 5% of quantity in Column 3 of Annex I
Injury to persons: >= 1 fatalities, >= 6 hospitalizing injuries etc.
Immediate damage to the environment (according to Annex VI)

AccidentDescription: <p>Fire on the floating roof of a tank containing virgin naphtha, after the naphtha had spilt out onto the floating roof and as the emptying of the tank was starting. The fire, which broke out at 00.50 on 27 September 2014, developed like a pool fire, i.e. like a fire in a pool of fuel, and was therefore confined to the area of the tank roof that was in contact with the fuel. In the safety report, an accident of this kind was considered to be possible. The fire continued throughout the night and was extinguished at about 10.30 on 27 September 2014.</p>

Site_Description: <p>The site consists of production, storage and service facilities.<br> The refinery’s production cycle takes place in plants used for the distillation process, where crude oil is separated out into its various fractions, such as gas, LPG, naphtha, kerosene, gasoils and residue. The distillation plant’s semi-finished products are feedstocks for conversion plants.<br> The storage area comprises 145 tanks, almost all of which are floating-roof vertical cylinders; they have a combined capacity of about 4&nbsp;000&nbsp;000 m<sup>3</sup>.<br> Storage has been adapted to the types of feedstocks and to the wide variety of products placed on the market: LPG, finished and semi-finished benzines, kerosene for various uses, gasoils and fuel oils.</p>
Installation_Description: <p>The accident involved tank TK&nbsp;513, which is located in the area of the refinery used for the atmospheric storage of feedstocks and products. It has a capacity of 100&nbsp;000 m<sup>3</sup> and a diameter of 82.2 m, and is 19&nbsp;m high. It is of the floating-roof type, with double leak protection. It is designed for the storage of virgin naphtha. Filling and emptying operations were carried out in TK&nbsp;513 in the days leading up to the accident.&nbsp;<br>To ensure that such operations are performed correctly, the refinery subjects the tank to a series of inspections to assess the condition of its components, both major (base, roof, shell, foundations and leakproofing) and minor (drains, vents, etc.) The refinery carries out checks every three months and every three years.<br>According to the refinery’s inspection system records, internal inspections of TK&nbsp;513 were carried out in 1985/86 and in 1998/99. The last general overhaul of the tank (1998/99) comprised the total replacement of its base and the application of protective epoxy paint, refurbishment of the tank’s main fittings (legs, shell-top access ways, surge pipes, stairways, coil, etc.) and the plating of parts of the topside of the caissons.<br>In addition, the company carried out UTS checks on TK&nbsp;513 in 2008, and checks on its shell with the aid of a robotic system in 2011 to measure the thickness over the full height of its surface. Both sets of checks found thicknesses to be in line with the nominal thickness.<br>TK 513 is equipped with a fire-protection system that comprises:&nbsp;a shell-cooling system, a roof-top foam distribution system and heat-sensitive cables.<br>The floating roof of TK&nbsp;513 was of the double-deck variety and equipped with double leakproofing.</p>

Description: <p>The company estimates that about 6&nbsp;000 tonnes of the product (virgin naphtha) went up in flames. <br> The quantities of products and categories of hazardous products at the refinery are such that its operation is subject to the requirements of Article&nbsp;9 of the Seveso&nbsp;II Directive.</p>

Causes_Description:
<p>Malfunctioning of the floating roof, which failed to ensure the required leakproofness, thus allowing the substance to spill out onto the roof. It is not known what caused the virgin naphtha vapours to rise even though the control procedures had been activated.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
Other: Fire on the floating roof of a tank of Virgin Nafta as a result of product leak (unidentified cause) and fire of the same despite the activation of the control procedure (unidentified cause).

CausesHumans.ItemDescription: operator health (includes ailments, intoxication, death, etc.)
wilful disobedience/failure to carry out duties

CausesExternals.ItemDescription: utilities failure (electricity, gas, water, steam air, etc.)

Consequence_Description: <p>The accident resulted in damage to the plant as it involved TK&nbsp;513, the virgin naphtha it contained, the ducts connecting other equipment in the accident area to the tank, as well as the tank's containment and extinguisher systems.<br />As the fire was a pool fire, the fuel&nbsp; was contained wholly within the area of the roof and thus burned solely on the floating caissons, the fire being confined within the internal walls of TK&nbsp;513.<br /> There were no spills or leakages into the containment basin, and no fire outbreak was recorded there.<br />The company&rsquo;s statements and the measurements and inspections carried out by the local Environmental Protection Agency branch indicate that there was no immediate damage to the environment or to persons. The air quality monitoring units did not record significant variations in the pollutant concentrations measured.&nbsp;<br /> This accident resulted in over EUR&nbsp;2&nbsp;million worth of material damage within the plant.<br /> The material damage was inspected within the refinery and was due to:&nbsp;<br /> - the loss of 6&nbsp;000 tonnes (company estimate) of virgin naphtha in the tank,<br /> - the total destruction of floating-roof tank TK&nbsp;513,<br /> - damage to the tank&rsquo;s containment and extinguishing systems and to connecting pipes,<br /> - damage to one of the company&rsquo;s own firefighting appliances,&nbsp;<br /> - the clean-up and refurbishment of connecting devices,<br /> - the costs to be incurred in rebuilding the tank.<br /> According to the company, the consequences of the accident in terms of cost amount to about EUR&nbsp;14&nbsp;290&nbsp;000.00, including:<br /> - approx. EUR&nbsp;4&nbsp;500&nbsp;000.00 for the 6&nbsp;000 tonnes of virgin naphtha that burned;&nbsp;<br /> - approx. EUR&nbsp;9&nbsp;790&nbsp;000.00 for the decommissioning and subsequent rebuilding of TK&nbsp;513.<br />During the fire, fire brigade and refinery staff attended to the tank and the tanks close to it, and these were monitored by checking the critical temperatures of the materials. Therefore, the tank did not collapse and spill its contents into the containment basin, but it buckled on one side at about 10&nbsp;m, of the initial 19&nbsp;m, from the base.<br />The tank-roof fire developed despite the measures taken, but the accident did not affect other installations or persons. It is clear that, although functioning, the fixed and mobile firefighting systems used during the accident did not enable the emergency services to keep the fire under control and/or to extinguish the fire immediately after its outbreak.<br />The Prefecture did not consider it necessary to put the external action plan (EEP) into action.</p>
